Award.AwardTitle: Theoretical Study of Auroral Radio Waves
Award.AbstractNarration:
The Earth's ionosphere is a plasma composed of approximately equal numbers of ions and electrons. In addition to gravity that affects all matter, electric and magnetic forces are important in determining the behavior of the ionospheric plasma. The plasma behaves as a fluid even if there are few collisions between particles because electric and magnetic forces act at a distance. Analogous to waves in the ocean, plasma waves transmit energy through the ionosphere. Electromagnetic, pressure and velocity fields in combination produce a wide variety of plasma waves. This wave environment is extremely complex with a range of generation mechanisms, wave frequencies, and source locations. However, because of this complexity, many of these waves and their generation mechanisms are poorly understood. The auroral region contributes significantly to the natural radio wave environment of the Earth. This project investigates auroral roar and its generation mechanisms, which are complex and nonlinear involving wave-wave and wave-particle interactions. Because the types of waves generated depend on plasma conditions and can be observed far from the source region, they provide a means to infer the characteristics of plasmas remotely. As a result, what is learned about waves in the auroral region can be used to interpret conditions in astrophysical and planetary environments where these same waves are generated.

To study the origins of auroral roar, this project uses, and develops further, weak turbulence theory. This, in itself, is an important outcome of the project. A main aim is to contribute to the development of a unifying theory of plasmas and radio emission observed in the Earth's ionosphere and magnetosphere. Non-linear studies of auroral roar are likely to lead to a deeper understanding of the fundamental physics of wave-particle interactions. Four problems are explored in some detail: (1) the formation of the fine frequency structure of auroral roar emissions; (2) the decay of intense upper hybrid waves into multiple harmonics and lower frequency waves; (3) nonlinear coalescence generation of 4fce auroral roar; and (4) decay instability of upper-hybrid, lower-hybrid, and Bernstein waves.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Among major findings that resulted from the scientific research project supported by NSF, the University of Maryland PI, Dr. Peter Yoon, analyzed the data taken by the recent NASA spacecraft Van Allen Probe. The space probe showed that the Earth's radiation belt is replete with high frequency electric field noise that exists in almost all geomagnetic conditions, and the noise peaks at a particular characteristic frequency called the upper hybrid frequency. In order to understand this phenomenon, Dr. Yoon developed a mathematical model, and with such a model he theoretically reproduced the observation, as shown in Figure 1. His technique can be applied to other spacecraft missions, and help further understand the electromagnetic environment of the near Earth universe, which is important for satellite operation, surveillance, and human exploration of space.

Physical processes taking place in the radiation belt is part of the larger class of phenomena, which includes electromagnetic processes in the Auroral regions. Consequently, Dr. Yoon’s research interest was substantially widened during the course of the research period that included not only the narrow Auroral physics, but also a broader inner magnetospheric physics and even the solar wind. 

In another primary research outcome, Dr. Yoon also analyzed another spacecraft data, namely, the data taken by NASA's WIND spacecraft. The WIND spacecraft is permanently located between the Sun and Earth, and continually observe the ionized gas emitted by the Sun, traveling through the interplanetary space, and ending up near Earth. Over many years, the WIND spacecraft collected a huge amount of measurements on the incoming ionized gas, called the solar wind. When plotted against two physical parameters, the collected data exhibits a distribution enclosed by a rhombic shape in the so-called anisotropy-beta space, as displayed in Figure 2 background. In order to understand and explain such a feature, Dr. Yoon developed a sophisticated mathematical model, and by employing his model, he reproduced a hypothetical collection of solar wind states, and traced their paths along the interplanetary space, until they ended up near Earth. In Figure 2, his model near the Sun is shown with white dots, the final states with red dots, and intervening paths shown with black curves. His mathematical model successfully explains the WIND data, as Figure 2 demonstrates, and it shows that his model can further be used in other contexts, which includes the contemporary spacecraft mission called the Parker Solar Probe, which was launched in August 2018, and which has received much media attention, for being the first man-made object to almost touch the Sun. Dr. Yoon's model may be employed to explain the data taken by the Parker Solar Probe mission, which will become available very soon (some preliminary data are already available).

During the course of the research project, Dr. Yoon made efforts to train and educate young scientists from the United States as well as from overseas. Specifically, he hosted a number of young researchers from Pakistan, giving them opportunities to participate in his research, thereby gaining valuable experience in contemporary scientific research. These activities were part of his effort to train and educate the next generation of scientists, particularly from scientifically under-priviliged countries. All of his activities involving the trainding and education were of no cost to the NSF Award.

Dr. Yoon widely collaborated with numerous international colleagues. Again, his collaborative efforts were at no cost basis. As a result of such collaborative endeavors, the PI's research also produced a number of important byproducts, including the fact that, together with his colleagues at Ruhr University, Bochum, Germany, he proposed a potentially ground breaking theory of the origin of cosmic magnetic field during the early Universe before the recombination era, a problem that were outstanding. His theory involves a fundamental concept in the physics of ionized gas called the spontaneous emission theory. It is conceptually analogous to the famous blackbody radiation theory, but for ionized gas, the spontaneously emitted physical quantity is large scale static magnetic field.

Through support from the NSF Award Dr. Yoon published more than 50 research papers in major scientific research journals, all of which were peer-reviewed.
